KEY.ST secret (26) 27'.CABINET.LEGISLATION COMMITTEE.PROHIBITION OF LOCKOUTS AND STRIKES IN CERTAIN INDUSTRIES UNTIL AFTER ENQUIRY.Note by the Minister of Health0In accordance with the Committee's request I circulate herewith, for the consideration of my colleagues, certain draft amendments to the latest revise (cp 32 (27)) of the Trade' Disputes and Trade Unions Bill which I have prepared in consultation wit h the President of the Board of Trade and i/ir-o Granville Ram; to give effect to my proposal that lockouts and strikes In certain Industries should be prohibited until after proper enquiry.(intld.) NoC.Ministry of Health, 8th February, 1927a- Trade Disputes and Trade Unions Bill.DRAFT AMENDMENTS SUGGESTED BY THE MINISTER OF HEALTH.Clause 1, page 1, Line 13, leave out from " com-" munity " to the end of line 17.page 2, leave out subsection (2) and insert the following subsection and clause :" (2) Any lockout or strike in an undertaking to which this subsection applies shall be an illegal lockout or strike unless all matters appearing to the Minister of Labour to be connected with or relevant to the dispute on account of which the lockout or strike takes place have been referred by him to a court of inquiry in accordance with the provisions of Part II. of the Industrial Courts Act, 1919, and either " (a) a period of thirty days has elapsed after the matters have been so referred as aforesaid; or" (b) a period of fourteen days has elapsed after the report (not being an interim report) of the court of inquiry upon the matters referred to them has been laid before Parliament:" Provided that all matters appearing to the Minister of Labour to be connected with or relevant to any trade dispute, whether existing or apprehended, in an under-taking to which this subsection applies shall be so referred by him as aforesaid if application is made to him in that behalf by either party to the dispute or if, in his opinion, there is reason to apprehend a lockout or strike in the undertaking on account of the dispute." This subsection applies to the undertakings mentioned in the First Schedule to this Act, and to any other undertaking to which it may be applied by an order made by a Secretary of State, so, however, that no such order shall have effect until it has been confirmed by a resolution passed by both Houses of Parliament declaring that it is contrary to the public interest that there should be a cessation of work in that undertaking.21-1 strikes.Penalties in " . (1) It shall not be lawful to commence or respect of continue or to apply any sums in furtherance or support illegal lock- 0f any lockout or strike declared by this Act to be outs and M1 -.J Jillegal." (2) If any person declares, instigates, furthers, or takes part in a lockout declared by this Act to be illegal he shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding five hundred pounds for each day or part of a day during which the lockout continues." (3) If any person instigates, furthers, or takes part in a strike declared by this Act to be illegal he shall be guilty of a misdemeanour." (4) The provisions of the Trade Disputes Act, 1906, shall not, nor shall the second proviso to sub-section (1) of section two of the Emergency Powers Act, 1920, apply to any act done in contemplation or furtherance of a strike which is by this Act declared to be illegal, and any such act shall not be deemed for the purposes of the Conspiracy and Protection of Property Act, 1875, to be done in contemplation or furtherance of a trade dispute."Clause 12, page 9, line 5, at end insert: " ' Lockout' means the closing of a place of employ-ment, or the suspension of work, or the refusal by an employer to continue to employ any number of persons employed by him in con-sequence of a dispute, done with a view to compelling those persons or to aid another employer in compelling persons employed by him, to accept terms or conditions of or affect-ing employment: "Clause 12, page 11, insert the following new schedule : " FIRST SCHEDULE." Undertakings in which Lockouts and Strikes are prohibited until aeter inquiry." Undertakings for the supply of food, water, gas, electric light or electric power:" Undertakings for the working of coal mines : " Railway, light railway, tramway, canal, inland naviga-tion, harbour, dock, pier, or other undertakings concerned with transport services :" Undertakings in which His Majesty or any Government Department is the employer:'" Trade Disputes and Trade Unions Bill.DRAFT AMENDMENTS SUGGESTED BY THE MINISTER OP HEALTH.XIV.
